```{r parameter_description, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}

# The parameters above are set to NA here, but when this rmd script is run from the shiny app then the parameters are passed with values.

# The first five parameters are general: 

# INT defines whether interface provides the parameter values - any value other than NA passed from the interface will tell this rmd script to use all parameters. The interface passes a value of 1 automatically.

# GRS sets whether there are growth stages defined for the innovation. A value of 1 shows that there are growth stages defined in a csv file, and that (some) of the climatic criteria should be evaluated for the specific growth stages

# SOS sets whether the season onset is spatially defined. If so, SOS has a value of 1 and the start of the growing period is set using a raster rather than the value in the growth stage csv file. Otherwise SOS is 0.

# Agg defines the aggregation factor. This can be set above in the header with an integer value, or can be passed from the interface. The larger the aggregation factor the quicker the computation. The minimum value is 1.

# RES defines whether 3-class suitability, 9-class suitability or both classes are computed. Computing both classes will increase the time to run the script!
#A value of 1 will only compute the 3-class suitability maps. A value of 2 will only compute the 9-class suitability map. A value of 3 will compute both suitability class maps.

# INN denotes the innovation, this is a unique code for each location/innovation and is used to locate the data and parameters that are used in IRM

```

```{r growth_stages02, results='asis', eval=grs_crit}

  # get the growth stages filename using the innovation parameter
  growth_stages_filename <-
    as.character(paste("tab_data/input/growth_stages_", params$INN1, ".csv", sep = ""))
  
  growth_stages <-  read.csv(here(growth_stages_filename))
  
  growth_stages %>%
    kable(digits = 3, caption = "Growth Stage Lengths") %>% kable_styling("striped", full_width = T) %>% print
  
# create a new table just for where growth stage has requirements
growth_stages_req <- dplyr::filter(growth_stages, (prec_criteria == 1 | temp_criteria == 1))
growth_stages_req_prec <- dplyr::filter(growth_stages, prec_criteria == 1)  
growth_stages_req_temp <- dplyr::filter(growth_stages, temp_criteria == 1)   
  
  
  # get the number of variables in growth_stages (excluding sowing/planting date and total length)
  
  # create a list of the growth stages and determine the start and end days of each growth period
  phen_tmp <- list()
  for (i in 1:(nrow(growth_stages) - 2)) {
    phen_tmp[[as.character(growth_stages[i + 1, 1])]] <-
      growth_stages[i + 1, 3]
  }
  
  phen_stages_beg <-
    growth_stages$day[1] + c(0, cumsum(phen_tmp)[-length(phen_tmp)])
  phen_stages_end <- growth_stages$day[1] + cumsum(phen_tmp)
  names(phen_stages_beg) <- names(phen_stages_end)
  
  # add the total to the growth stages
  
  phen_stages_beg[["total"]] <- growth_stages[1, 2]
  phen_stages_end[["total"]] <-
    sum(growth_stages[1, 2], growth_stages[2, 3])
  
  rbind(start = phen_stages_beg, end = phen_stages_end) %>%
    as.data.frame %>%
    kable(caption = "Growth Stage Days") %>% kable_styling("striped", full_width = T)  %>% print
  
  
  num_years <- ceiling(phen_stages_end[["total"]] / 365)
  cat(paste("Growth Stages span", num_years, "calendar years"))
  
```

# Load Spatial Data

Here we load all the spatial data. The data are used in different chunks below but it is easier to modify filenames if all the spatial data are imported in the same chunk.

## Vector Data

The vector data include the sub-divisions of the area that is being modelled, and triangulation points if available.

The vector data are not projected and in geojson format. Here they are loaded and projected to the working crs

# Common spatial resolution and extent

## Mask

Let's start with creating a 'mask', _i.e._, a raster map of the area of interest (1 = area to be modelled, NA = ignored). 

The properties of this map are given below:

<div class="fold o">  
```{r mask01, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, out.width="100%", warning=FALSE}

if (params$Agg == 1){rast_mask_proj <- rast_subdiv_mask_proj} else {
  rast_mask_proj <- aggregate(rast_subdiv_mask_proj, fact = params$Agg, expand = TRUE)}


g <- base_raster_plot(rast_mask_proj, "layer", 'red', 'blue', paste0("Aggregated mask - Resolution = ", res(rast_mask_proj), "m"))

gsubdivsimple <- add_subdiv_simple_plot(g)
gsubdivsimple


```
</div>

A factor is calculated to determine the area of each raster cell in hectares.

```{r mask02, cache = FALSE, warning=FALSE }

Stat_factor_ha <- ((xres(rast_mask_proj)^2) / 10000) # factor used for statistical calculations divides the area of a raster cell (in m2) by 10000 to give the area of the cell in hectares 

cat(paste(Stat_factor_ha, "hectares in each cell"))

```

This mask designates the locations where predictions should be made, and an empty dataframe (tibble) is created with records for all locations.


<div class="fold o">   
```{r mask03, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, warning=FALSE }

# only run the models for the areas in the mask

cond_data <- geom(terra::as.points(rast_mask_proj)) %>% as_tibble()

x <-  pull(cond_data, x)
y <-  pull(cond_data, y)
xy <- cbind(x, y)

str(cond_data)

if (params$INT == 1)
  shiny::setProgress(0.17, message = "Resampling data 1st Innovation")  # set progress to 17%
```

```{r agg_resample_01, cache = TRUE, out.width="100%", results='asis', warning=FALSE}
# when not different just create a new raster with the same prj suffix

    paste0("rast_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_prj"),
    get(paste0("rast_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_roughcrop"))
      )
  }

# calculate aggregate factor for each criterion for both dimensions of the raster (these are the same for a square cell shape)
  
  cat(paste(raster_data_df[i, 10]))
  cat("\n")

  calc_agg_factor <-
    (res(rast_mask_proj) / res(get(paste0(
      "rast_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_prj"
    ))))
  cat(paste("calculated aggregate factor = ", calc_agg_factor))
  cat("\n")
  
 if (calc_agg_factor[1] < 1) {
    calc_agg_factor[1] <- 1
    
    # this means that the mask has a higher resolution than the precipitation raster so aggregation is not necessary and the precipitation raster will stay the same resolution
    
    cat(paste("revised calculated aggregate factor 1 = ", calc_agg_factor[1]))
    cat("\n")
  }
  
  
  
  if (calc_agg_factor[2] < 1) {
    calc_agg_factor[2] <- 1
    cat(paste("revised calculated aggregate factor 2 = ", calc_agg_factor[2]))
  }
  
  # for each record in the raster_data_df data frame use the data file prefix to recreate the raster name, and the aggregation and resample functions
  cat(paste("aggregate and resample"))
  assign(
    paste0("rast_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_rsmp"),
    agg_resample(
      get(paste0("rast_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_prj")),
      calc_agg_factor,
      as.character(raster_data_df[i, 13]),
      as.character(raster_data_df[i, 14])
    )
  )
  
  plot_raster <-
    terra::plot(
      get(paste0("rast_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_rsmp")),
      main = paste0(
        as.character(raster_data_df[i, 10]),
        "\nagg ",
        as.character(raster_data_df[i, 13]),
        " rsmp ",
        as.character(raster_data_df[i, 14])
      ),
      breaks = 10
   )
  #print(plot_raster)
  
  cat("\n")
  cat(paste("Dim = ", dim(get(paste0("rast_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_rsmp")))))
  cat("\n\n")
  
  plot_raster
#  terra::plot(rast_mask_proj, title = "") # this is needed (even if it is not actually plotted) to enable the plot of the raster
  
}
```

# Requirements for successful production and adoption

In this section the requirements for production and adoption are given in terms of membership functions defined by fuzzy partitions. The membership functions are applied to the data, and can be considered as the lowest level rule bases - seen in the green boxes in the figure of the rule bases above.

The requirements are described and applied first for bio-physical criteria (if defined) and then for socio-economic criteria (if defined).

```{r sowing_dates_sos_maps_m, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, fig.width=8, fig.height=7, out.width="100%", warning=FALSE, eval=grs_crit, eval=sos_crit}

# to reduce unnecessary processing follow these steps
# for each growth stage:

# (1) does the monthly and/or dekad raster mask exist on file?
#   YES - (i) load raster file to env
#         (ii) plot raster file
#         (iii) move to next growth stage or next chunk
#   NO -  (i) go to (2)

# (2) does the monthly and/or dekad raster mask csv exist on file?
#   YES - (i) load csv file to env as vect
#         (ii) rasterize vect
#         (iii) write raster to file
#         (iv) go to (1)
#   NO -  (i) go to (3)

# (3) does the monthly and/or dekad raster mask df exist in the env?
#   YES - (i) write df to file as csv
#         (ii) go to (2)
#   NO -  (i) go to (4)

# (4) does the monthly and/or dekad raster mask matrix exist in the env?
#   YES - (i) join the matrix to the onset df
#         (ii) write df to file as csv
#         (iii) go to (3)
#   NO -  (i) create the matrix using the growth_period_long functions
#         (ii) join the matrix to the onset df
#         (iii) go to (4)

if (exists('clim_mask_m')) {
  cat(paste("\n1 Monthly data exist"))
  
  for (i in 1:(nrow(growth_stages_lengths))) {
    period_name <- as.character(growth_stages_lengths[i, 1])
    cat(paste("\nCurrent growth stage = ", period_name))
    
    rast_filename_m <-
      as.character(paste0(
        "spatial_data/output/rast_",
        period_name,
        "_m_",
        params$INN1,
        ".tif"
      ))
    
    if (!file.exists(here(rast_filename_m))) {
      cat(paste("\n2 No spatraster"))
      
      if (!exists(paste0("vect_", period_name, "_m"))) {
        cat(paste("\n3 No spatvector"))
        
        csv_filename_m <-
          as.character(
            paste(
              "tab_data/output/onset_df_",
              period_name,
              "_m_",
              params$INN1,
              ".csv",
              sep = ""
            )
          )
        
        if (!file.exists(here(csv_filename_m))) {
          cat(paste("\n4 No csv data"))
          
          if (!exists(paste0("onset_df_", period_name, "_m"))) {
            cat(paste("\n5 No df"))
            
            if (!exists(paste0(period_name, "_matrix_days_m"))) {
              cat(paste("\n6 No matrix"))
              
              if (period_name == "total") {
                expr_3_m <- parse(
                  text = paste0(
                    "t(apply(onset_df, 1, .growth_period_long_tbl, day_begin = \"onset\", day_end = \"",
                    growth_stages_lengths[nrow(growth_stages_lengths) - 1, 1],
                    "_e\", num_years = num_years))"
                  )
                )
              } else {
                expr_3_m <- parse(
                  text = paste0(
                    "t(apply(onset_df, 1, .growth_period_long_tbl, day_begin = \"",
                    period_name,
                    "_s\",
        day_end = \"",
        period_name,
        "_e\", num_years = num_years))"
                  )
                )
              }
              
              assign(paste0(period_name, "_matrix_days_m"),
                     eval(expr_3_m))
              
              cat(paste("\n-6"))
            }
            
            
            assign(paste0("onset_df_", period_name, "_m"),
                   data.frame(onset_df, get(
                     paste0(period_name, "_matrix_days_m")
                   )))
            cat(paste("\n-5"))
          }
          
          
          
          write.csv(get(paste0("onset_df_", period_name, "_m")),
                    here(csv_filename_m))
          
          cat(paste("\n-4"))
        }
        
        assign(paste0("vect_", period_name, "_m"),
               vect(
                 read_csv(here(csv_filename_m), show_col_types = FALSE),
                 geom = c("x", "y"),
                 crs = wkt_lam
               ))
        cat(paste("\n-3"))
      }
      
      
      assign(paste0("list_rast_", period_name, "_m"),
             list())
      
      #create an empty raster
      assign(paste0("rast_", period_name, "_m"), rast())
      
      for (j in 1:12) {
        assign(
          paste0("rast_", period_name, "_m_", j),
          rasterize(get(
            paste0("vect_", period_name, "_m")
          ), clim_mask_m, field = paste0("X", j))
        )
        
        assign(paste0("list_rast_", period_name, "_m"),
               append(get(
                 paste0("list_rast_", period_name, "_m")
               ), paste0("rast_", period_name, "_m_", j)))
        expr_5_m <-
          parse(text = paste0(
            "add(rast_",
            period_name,
            "_m) <- (rast_",
            period_name,
            "_m_",
            j,
            ")"
          ))
        
        eval(expr_5_m)
      }
      
      
      writeRaster(get(paste0("rast_", period_name, "_m")), here(rast_filename_m), overwrite = TRUE)
      cat(paste("\n-2"))
    }
    
    assign(paste0("rast_", period_name, "_m"), rast(here(rast_filename_m)))
    cat(paste0("\n", rast_filename_m))
    
    expr_6_m <-
      parse(
        text = paste0(
          "names(rast_",
          period_name,
          "_m) <- c(\"January\", \"February\", \"March\", \"April\",\"May\",\"June\",\"July\",\"August\",\"September\",\"October\",\"November\",\"December\")"
        )
      )
    
    eval(expr_6_m)
    
    plot(
      get(paste0("rast_", period_name, "_m")),
      maxnl = 12,
      breaks = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1),
      axes = F,
      plg = list(cex = 1, title = paste0(period_name))
    )
    
  }
  cat(paste("\n-1"))
}

```

```{r requirements_prec04, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, fig.width=7, fig.height=4, out.width="100%", fig.show="hold", warning=FALSE, eval=prec_crit, eval=grs_crit}

for (i in 1:(nrow(criteria_ba3a))) {
  if (!is.na(criteria_ba3a[i, 18])) {
    # for those criteria with three proposition values
    # get  the 3 proposition levels
    prop_levels <-
      c(
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 16]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 17]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 18])
      )
    
    # get  the 3 conclusion levels
    conc_levels <-
      c(
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 20]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 21])
      )
    # get  the 2 crossover points
    cross_points <-
      c(criteria_ba3a[i, 6],
        criteria_ba3a[i, 7])
    
    # get  the 2 transition widths
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_ba3a[i, 8],
        criteria_ba3a[i, 9])
    
    # get  the 2 xlims for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_ba3a[i, 6] - criteria_ba3a[i, 8]),
        (criteria_ba3a[i, 7] + criteria_ba3a[i, 9]))
    
    
  } else {
    # for those criteria with two proposition values
    # get  the 2 proposition levels
    prop_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 16]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 17]))
    
    # get  the 2 conclusion levels
    conc_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 20]))
    
    # get  the 1 crossover point
    cross_points <-
      c(criteria_ba3a[i, 6])
    
    # get  the 1 transition width
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_ba3a[i, 8])
    
    # get  the 1 xlim for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_ba3a[i, 6] - criteria_ba3a[i, 8]),
        (criteria_ba3a[i, 6] + criteria_ba3a[i, 8]))
    
  }
  assign(
    paste0("fp_", criteria_ba3a[i, 3]),
    LinearFuzzyPartition(
      level =  prop_levels,
      crossoverPoint  = cross_points,
      transitionWidth = trans_width
    )
  )
  
  plot_fp <-
    plot(
      get(paste0("fp_", criteria_ba3a[i, 3])),
      xlim = plot_xlim,
      xlab = as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 4]),
      title = "fuzzy partition"
    )
  print(plot_fp)
  
  # construct the rule bases
  
  
  # set the proposition name
  Prop_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 3]))
  # set the conclusion name
  Conc_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 3]),
           "_o")
  
  # thanks to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45741498/add-column-in-tibble-with-variable-column-name for the following dynamic assignment of variable names in a tibble
  
  # set the proposition values
  p_tib <- tibble(!!Prop_name := c(prop_levels))
  # set the conclusion values
  c_tib <- tibble(!!Conc_name := c(conc_levels))
  
  # new proposition and conclusion class objects are made here
  new_prop <- new("Proposition", table = p_tib)
  new_conc <- new("Conclusion", table = c_tib)
  
  assign(paste0("rb_",
                criteria_ba3a[i, 3]),
         
         RuleBase(new_prop, new_conc))
  
  print(get(paste0("rb_",
                   criteria_ba3a[i, 3])))
  
  # apply the fuzzy partitions to the data
  
  # first construct the predict function with all arguments as text
  
  x <- paste0(
    "predict(rb_",
    criteria_ba3a[i, 3],
    ", newdata = cond_data,",
    criteria_ba3a[i, 3],
    "=",
    "fp_",
    criteria_ba3a[i, 3],
    ")"
  )
  
  
  assign(paste0("fpm_",
                criteria_ba3a[i, 3]), eval(parse(text = x)))
  
  
  o_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_ba3a[i, 3]))$optimal)
  s_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_ba3a[i, 3]))$suboptimal)
  cond_data <-
    mutate(cond_data,!!as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 3], "_o")) := o_col, .keep = c("all"))
  cond_data <-
    mutate(cond_data,!!as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 3], "_s")) := s_col, .keep = c("all"))
  
  n <- 2
  fpm_conc_var <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 3], "_o")), as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 3], "_s")), "x" , "y")
  fpm_conc_name <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 4], " optimal")), as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 4], " suboptimal")))
  fpm_plot_title <-
    "Precipitation growth\nstages optimality\nmembership"
  
  plot_fpm <- rasterize_plot_fpm(n, fpm_conc_var, fpm_conc_name, cond_data)
  print(plot_fpm)
  
  
}
``` 

```{r requirements_soilp01, echo=FALSE, results='asis', eval=soil_p_crit}
If soil texture is a criterion then the USDA codes are reclassified quantitatively so that the fuzzy partitions can be applied.

Soil texture classes are reclassified in with 1, corresponding to S1 in Sys _et al._ (1993, p.159), 0.5 corresponding to S2, and 0 corresponding to S3, N1, N2 in Sys _et al._.

USDA Class | USDA Texture Code | Suitability | Value 
-----------|-------------------|-------------|-------
     '1'   |     'Cl'          |  S2         |  0.5
     '2'   |     'SiCl'        |  S1         |  1
     '3'   |     'SaCl'        |  S1         |  1
     '4'   |     'ClLo'        |  S1         |  1
     '5'   |     'SiClLo'      |  S1         |  1
     '6'   |     'SaClLo'      |  S1         |  1
     '7'   |     'Lo'          |  S1         |  1
     '8'   |     'SiLo'        |  S1         |  1
     '9'   |     'SaLo'        |  S1         |  1
    '10'   |     'Si'          |  S1         |  1
    '11'   |     'LoSa'        |  S1         |  1

   '255'   |     'NODATA'      |  NA         |  NA")
```

```{r requirements_soilp02, results='asis', warning=FALSE, eval=soil_p_crit}

# Each innovation has potentially different criteria and rule bases

# In this chunk we need to know which data to load for the criteria

criteria_ba2c <-
  subset(priorities, grepl("^ba_2c", priorities$rulebase_stack)) # use regular expressions to find criteria
n_cba2c <- nrow(criteria_ba2c)
cat(paste(n_cba2c, "Soil physical properties criteria:\n\n"))

# then determine and print the names of the rule bases in the soil physical properties theme
cat(paste(n_cba2c, "Soil physical properties rule bases:\n\n"))
for (i in 1:n_cba2c) {
  cat(paste(criteria_ba2c[i, 3],"\n", criteria_ba2c[i, 4],"\n"))
  
  if (paste(criteria_ba2c[i, 4]) == "Soil texture") {
    soil_texture_filename <-
      as.character(paste("tab_data/input/usda_texture_", params$INN1, ".csv", sep = ""))
    
    soil_texture <-  read.csv(here(soil_texture_filename))
    
    soil_texture %>%
      kable(digits = 3, caption = "Soil Texture ") %>% kable_styling("striped", full_width = T) %>% print
    
    # reclass using soil_texture table
    
    rast_texture <-
      get(paste0("rast_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp")) %>% classify(as.matrix(
        dplyr::select(soil_texture, USDA_Texture_Class, IRM_Value)
      ))
    
    
    assign(paste0("rast_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"),  rast_texture[[1:5]])
    
    # standard depths for interpolation
    standard_depths <- c(0.025, 0.10, 0.225, 0.45, 0.80, 1.50)
    
    # thicknesses of individual layers
    bottom_layer <- c(0.05, 0.15, 0.30, 0.60, 1.0)
    thickness <- diff(c(0, bottom_layer))
    stopifnot(max(abs(
      bottom_layer - 0.5 *  thickness - standard_depths[1:5]
    )) < 1.0e-6)
    
    # depth weighted texture class (0-1)
    assign(paste0("rast_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"),
           get(paste0("rast_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp")) %>% app(function(x) {
             sum((x * thickness) / sum(thickness))
           }))
  } else if (paste(criteria_ba2c[i, 4]) == "Coarse fragments") {
    assign(paste0("rast_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"),  get(paste0("rast_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"))[[1:5]])
    
    # standard depths for interpolation
    standard_depths <- c(0.025, 0.10, 0.225, 0.45, 0.80, 1.50)
    
    # thicknesses of individual layers
    bottom_layer <- c(0.05, 0.15, 0.30, 0.60, 1.0)
    thickness <- diff(c(0, bottom_layer))
    stopifnot(max(abs(
      bottom_layer - 0.5 *  thickness - standard_depths[1:5]
    )) < 1.0e-6)
    
    # depth weighted map
    assign(paste0("rast_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"),
           get(paste0("rast_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp")) %>% app(function(x) {
             sum((x * thickness) / sum(thickness))
           }))
  }
}
```

```{r requirements_lscape05, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, fig.width=7, fig.height=4, out.width="100%", fig.show="hold", warning=FALSE, eval=lscape_crit}
for (i in 1:(nrow(criteria_ba2e))) {
  if (!is.na(criteria_ba2e[i, 18])) {
    # for those criteria with three proposition values
    # get  the 3 proposition levels
    prop_levels <-
      c(
        as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 16]),
        as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 17]),
        as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 18])
      )
    
    # get  the 3 conclusion levels
    conc_levels <-
      c(
        as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 20]),
        as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 21])
      )
    # get  the 2 crossover points
    cross_points <-
      c(criteria_ba2e[i, 6],
        criteria_ba2e[i, 7])
    
    # get  the 2 transition widths
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_ba2e[i, 8],
        criteria_ba2e[i, 9])
    
    # get  the 2 xlims for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_ba2e[i, 6] - criteria_ba2e[i, 8]),
        (criteria_ba2e[i, 7] + criteria_ba2e[i, 9]))
    
    
  } else {
    # for those criteria with two proposition values
    # get  the 2 proposition levels
    prop_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 16]),
        as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 17]))
    
    # get  the 2 conclusion levels
    conc_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 20]))
    
    # get  the 1 crossover point
    cross_points <-
      c(criteria_ba2e[i, 6])
    
    # get  the 1 transition width
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_ba2e[i, 8])
    
    # get  the 1 xlim for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_ba2e[i, 6] - criteria_ba2e[i, 8]),
        (criteria_ba2e[i, 6] + criteria_ba2e[i, 8]))
    
  }
  assign(
    paste0("fp_", criteria_ba2e[i, 3]),
    LinearFuzzyPartition(
      level =  prop_levels,
      crossoverPoint  = cross_points,
      transitionWidth = trans_width
    )
  )
  
  plot_fp <-
    plot(
      get(paste0("fp_", criteria_ba2e[i, 3])),
      xlim = plot_xlim,
      xlab = as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 4]),
      title = "fuzzy partition"
    )
  print(plot_fp)
  
  # construct the rule bases
  
  
  # set the proposition name
  Prop_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 3]))
  # set the conclusion name
  Conc_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_ba2e[i, 3]),
           "_o")
  
  # thanks to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45741498/add-column-in-tibble-with-variable-column-name for the following dynamic assignment of variable names in a tibble
  
  # set the proposition values
  p_tib <- tibble(!!Prop_name := c(prop_levels))
  # set the conclusion values
  c_tib <- tibble(!!Conc_name := c(conc_levels))
  
  # new proposition and conclusion class objects are made here
  new_prop <- new("Proposition", table = p_tib)
  new_conc <- new("Conclusion", table = c_tib)
  
  assign(paste0("rb_",
                criteria_ba2e[i, 3]),
         
         RuleBase(new_prop, new_conc))
  
  print(get(paste0("rb_",
                   criteria_ba2e[i, 3])))
  
  # apply the fuzzy partitions to the data
  
  
  # first construct the predict function with all arguments as text
  
  x <- paste0(
    "predict(rb_",
    criteria_ba2e[i, 3],
    ", newdata = cond_data,",
    criteria_ba2e[i, 3],
    "=",
    "fp_",
    criteria_ba2e[i, 3],
    ")"
  )
  
  # evaluate the rule base and create the fpm
  
  assign(paste0("fpm_",
                criteria_ba2e[i, 3]), eval(parse(text = x)))
  
  # get the membership values from the fpm
  
  o_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_ba2e[i, 3]))$optimal)
  s_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_ba2e[i, 3]))$suboptimal)
  cond_data <-
    mutate(cond_data, !!as.character(paste0(criteria_ba2e[i, 3], "_o")) := o_col, .keep = c("all"))
  cond_data <-
    mutate(cond_data, !!as.character(paste0(criteria_ba2e[i, 3], "_s")) := s_col, .keep = c("all"))
  
  n = 2
  fpm_conc_var <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_ba2e[i, 3], "_o")), as.character(paste0(criteria_ba2e[i, 3], "_s")), "x" , "y")
  fpm_conc_name <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_ba2e[i, 4], " optimal")), as.character(paste0(criteria_ba2e[i, 4], " suboptimal")))
  fpm_plot_title <-
    "Landscape optimality membership"
  
  plot_fpm <- rasterize_plot_fpm(n, fpm_conc_var, fpm_conc_name, cond_data)
  print(plot_fpm)

}
``` 

```{r requirements_inputs_access05, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, fig.width=7, fig.height=4, out.width="100%", fig.show="hold", warning=FALSE, eval=inpaccess_crit}
for (i in 1:(nrow(criteria_se3b))) {
  if (!is.na(criteria_se3b[i, 18])) {
    # for those criteria with three proposition values
    # get  the 3 proposition levels
    prop_levels <-
      c(
        as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 16]),
        as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 17]),
        as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 18])
      )
    
    # get  the 3 conclusion levels
    conc_levels <-
      c(
        as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 20]),
        as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 21])
      )
    # get  the 2 crossover points
    cross_points <-
      c(criteria_se3b[i, 6],
        criteria_se3b[i, 7])
    
    # get  the 2 transition widths
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_se3b[i, 8],
        criteria_se3b[i, 9])
    
    # get  the 2 xlims for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_se3b[i, 6] - criteria_se3b[i, 8]),
        (criteria_se3b[i, 7] + criteria_se3b[i, 9]))
    
    
  } else {
    # for those criteria with two proposition values
    # get  the 2 proposition levels
    prop_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 16]),
        as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 17]))
    
    # get  the 2 conclusion levels
    conc_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 20]))
    
    # get  the 1 crossover point
    cross_points <-
      c(criteria_se3b[i, 6])
    
    # get  the 1 transition width
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_se3b[i, 8])
    
    # get  the 1 xlim for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_se3b[i, 6] - criteria_se3b[i, 8]),
        (criteria_se3b[i, 6] + criteria_se3b[i, 8]))
    
  }
  assign(
    paste0("fp_", criteria_se3b[i, 3]),
    LinearFuzzyPartition(
      level =  prop_levels,
      crossoverPoint  = cross_points,
      transitionWidth = trans_width
    )
  )
  
  plot_fp <-
    plot(
      get(paste0("fp_", criteria_se3b[i, 3])),
      xlim = plot_xlim,
      xlab = as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 4]),
      title = "fuzzy partition"
    )
  print(plot_fp)
  
  # construct the rule bases
  
  
  # set the proposition name
  Prop_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 3]))
  # set the conclusion name
  Conc_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_se3b[i, 3]),
           "_o")
  
  # thanks to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45741498/add-column-in-tibble-with-variable-column-name for the following dynamic assignment of variable names in a tibble
  
  # set the proposition values
  p_tib <- tibble(!!Prop_name := c(prop_levels))
  # set the conclusion values
  c_tib <- tibble(!!Conc_name := c(conc_levels))
  
  # new proposition and conclusion class objects are made here
  new_prop <- new("Proposition", table = p_tib)
  new_conc <- new("Conclusion", table = c_tib)
  
  assign(paste0("rb_",
                criteria_se3b[i, 3]),
         
         RuleBase(new_prop, new_conc))
  
  print(get(paste0("rb_",
                   criteria_se3b[i, 3])))
  
  # apply the fuzzy partitions to the data
  
  
  # first construct the predict function with all arguments as text
  
  x <- paste0(
    "predict(rb_",
    criteria_se3b[i, 3],
    ", newdata = cond_data,",
    criteria_se3b[i, 3],
    "=",
    "fp_",
    criteria_se3b[i, 3],
    ")"
  )
  
  # evaluate the rule base and create the fpm
  
  assign(paste0("fpm_",
                criteria_se3b[i, 3]), eval(parse(text = x)))
  
  # get the membership values from the fpm
  
  g_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_se3b[i, 3]))$good)
  p_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_se3b[i, 3]))$poor)
  cond_data <-
    mutate(cond_data, !!as.character(paste0(criteria_se3b[i, 3], "_g")) := g_col, .keep = c("all"))
  cond_data <-
    mutate(cond_data, !!as.character(paste0(criteria_se3b[i, 3], "_p")) := p_col, .keep = c("all"))
  
  n = 2
  fpm_conc_var <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_se3b[i, 3], "_g")), as.character(paste0(criteria_se3b[i, 3], "_p")), "x" , "y")
  fpm_conc_name <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_se3b[i, 4], " good")), as.character(paste0(criteria_se3b[i, 4], " poor")))
  fpm_plot_title <-
    "Inputs Access\noptimality\nmembership"
  
  plot_fpm <- rasterize_plot_fpm(n, fpm_conc_var, fpm_conc_name, cond_data)
  print(plot_fpm)
  
  
}
``` 

```{r requirements_fp_access05, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, fig.width=7, fig.height=4, out.width="100%", fig.show="hold", warning=FALSE, eval=fp_crit}
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_se4c[i, 8],
        criteria_se4c[i, 9])
    
    # get  the 2 xlims for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_se4c[i, 6] - criteria_se4c[i, 8]),
        (criteria_se4c[i, 7] + criteria_se4c[i, 9]))
    
    
  } else {
    # for those criteria with two proposition values
    # get  the 2 proposition levels
    prop_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_se4c[i, 16]),
        as.character(criteria_se4c[i, 17]))
    
    # get  the 2 conclusion levels
    conc_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_se4c[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_se4c[i, 20]))
    
    # get  the 1 crossover point
    cross_points <-
      c(criteria_se4c[i, 6])
    
    # get  the 1 transition width
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_se4c[i, 8])
    
    # get  the 1 xlim for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_se4c[i, 6] - criteria_se4c[i, 8]),
        (criteria_se4c[i, 6] + criteria_se4c[i, 8]))
    
  }
  assign(
    paste0("fp_", criteria_se4c[i, 3]),
    LinearFuzzyPartition(
      level =  prop_levels,
      crossoverPoint  = cross_points,
      transitionWidth = trans_width
    )
  )
  
  plot_fp <-
    plot(
      get(paste0("fp_", criteria_se4c[i, 3])),
      xlim = plot_xlim,
      xlab = as.character(criteria_se4c[i, 4]),
      title = "fuzzy partition"
    )
  print(plot_fp)
  
  # construct the rule bases
  
  
  # set the proposition name
  Prop_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_se4c[i, 3]))
  # set the conclusion name
  Conc_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_se4c[i, 3]),
           "_o")
  
  # thanks to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45741498/add-column-in-tibble-with-variable-column-name for the following dynamic assignment of variable names in a tibble
  
  # set the proposition values
  p_tib <- tibble(!!Prop_name := c(prop_levels))
  # set the conclusion values
  c_tib <- tibble(!!Conc_name := c(conc_levels))
  
  # new proposition and conclusion class objects are made here
  new_prop <- new("Proposition", table = p_tib)
  new_conc <- new("Conclusion", table = c_tib)
  
  assign(paste0("rb_",
                criteria_se4c[i, 3]),
         
         RuleBase(new_prop, new_conc))
  
  print(get(paste0("rb_",
                   criteria_se4c[i, 3])))
  
  # apply the fuzzy partitions to the data
  
  
  # first construct the predict function with all arguments as text
  
  x <- paste0(
    "predict(rb_",
    criteria_se4c[i, 3],
    ", newdata = cond_data,",
    criteria_se4c[i, 3],
    "=",
    "fp_",
    criteria_se4c[i, 3],
    ")"
  )
  
  # evaluate the rule base and create the fpm
  
  assign(paste0("fpm_",
                criteria_se4c[i, 3]), eval(parse(text = x)))
  
  # get the membership values from the fpm
  
  g_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_se4c[i, 3]))$good)
  p_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_se4c[i, 3]))$poor)
  cond_data <-
    mutate(cond_data, !!as.character(paste0(criteria_se4c[i, 3], "_g")) := g_col, .keep = c("all"))
  cond_data <-
    mutate(cond_data, !!as.character(paste0(criteria_se4c[i, 3], "_p")) := p_col, .keep = c("all"))
  
  n = 2
  fpm_conc_var <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_se4c[i, 3], "_g")), as.character(paste0(criteria_se4c[i, 3], "_p")), "x" , "y")
  fpm_conc_name <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_se4c[i, 4], " good")), as.character(paste0(criteria_se4c[i, 4], " poor")))
  fpm_plot_title <-
    "Fertilisers\nand Pesticides\noptimality\nmembership"
  
  plot_fpm <- rasterize_plot_fpm(n, fpm_conc_var, fpm_conc_name, cond_data)
  print(plot_fpm)
  
  
}
``` 

# Rule Base Creation and Evaluation

We will not construct one big rule base but follow a hierarchical approach consisting of many small interrelated rule bases for the following reasons:

- one big rule base is hard, if not impossible, to understand
- a set of smaller hierarchically organised rule bases gives more information about the limiting factors
- a hierarchically structured rule base is much faster and less memory demanding.
- a hierarchically structured rule base gives exactly the same results as one big rule base.

If we have both bio-physical and socio-economic criteria then these have separate rule bases, and are combined to give the Likelihood for Adoption.

```{r rulebases_ba01, echo=FALSE, results='asis', eval=ba_crit}
cat("## Bio-physical rule bases

There are no weights attached to the biophysical rule bases and it would be possible to create a single rule base with each criterion as propositions. However, this would be difficult to visualise and to interpret.

By constructing and evaluating smaller thematic rule bases it is possible to identify criteria that limit the biophysical aptitude.
")
```

```{r rulebases_ba03, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, cache.whatever=params$Agg, warning=FALSE, eval=ba_crit}
             paste0("rbs_", criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_list")
           ), get(
             paste0("rbs_", criteria_ba1[i, 3], "_list")
           )))
    
    assign(paste0("fp_", criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_list"),
           append(get(paste0(
             "fp_", criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_list"
           )), get(paste0(
             "fp_", criteria_ba1[i, 3], "_list"
           ))))
    
    # set the proposition name
    # normally this is just the rule base number, but for ag land this number should be suffixed with "_o"
    if (paste0(as.character(criteria_ba1[i, 3])) == "ba_2a") {
      Prop_name <-
        paste0(as.character(criteria_ba1[i, 3]), "_o")
    }
    else{
      Prop_name <-
        paste0(as.character(criteria_ba1[i, 3]))
    }
    
    # get  the 2 conclusion levels and get the unique values
    prop_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_ba1[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_ba1[i, 20]))  %>% unique()
    
    
    # set the proposition values
    if (!exists("p_tib")) {
      p_tib <- tibble(!!Prop_name := c(prop_levels))
    } else {
      #new_p_tib <- tibble(!!Prop_name := c(prop_levels))
      p_tib <-
        bind_cols(p_tib, tibble(!!Prop_name := c(prop_levels)))
    }
  }

 
  # new proposition object is made here
  prop <- new("Proposition", table = p_tib %>% cross_df)
  prop_table <- prop@table
  n_prop <- ncol(prop_table)
  
  
  # new conclusion object is made here
  # needs to more or less replicate the original ifelse construction:
  
  # build the ifelse expression based on number of propositions
  
  x <- 1
  z <- NULL
  while (x <= n_prop)  {
    z <- paste0(z, "(prop_table[", x, "] == \"optimal\") &")
    x <- x + 1
  }
  
  z <-
    paste0("ifelse ((", z, " 1 == 1), \"optimal\", \"suboptimal\")")
  c_tib <- NULL
  
  # evaluate the ifelse expression to produce a conclusion table and class
  c_tib <- eval(parse(text = z)) %>% as_tibble()
  names(c_tib) <- criteria_ba1[1, 2] # this works
  conc <- new("Conclusion", table = c_tib)
  
  # create a rule base
assign(paste0("rb_", criteria_ba1[1, 2]), RuleBase(prop, conc)) %>% print()
  
  # add to the list of previous rule bases
  
  assign(paste0("rbs_", criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_list"),
         append(get(
           paste0("rbs_", criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_list")
         ), paste0("rb_", criteria_ba1[1, 2])))


  
  # create the rule base stack from the list
  
  # original rbs_tmp_aptitude <- stack(rb_tmp_g_4a, rb_tmp_v_4b, rb_tmp_f_4c, rb_tmp_r_4d, rb_P_3a)
  
  x <-
    paste("stack(", gsub(",$", "", paste0(
      get(paste0("rbs_", criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_list")), sep = ",", collapse = ""
    )), ")")
 
  tmp_rbs <-  assign(paste0("rbs_", criteria_ba1[1, 2]), eval(parse(text = x)))

   # evaluate the rule base stack

    w <-
      paste("predict(", "tmp_rbs, newdata = cond_data,", gsub(",$", "", paste0(
        get(paste0("fp_", criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_list")), sep = ",", collapse = ""
      )), ")")
    
    assign(paste0("fpm_", criteria_ba1[1, 2]), eval(parse(text = w)))
  
 
    o_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                      criteria_ba1[1, 2]))$optimal)
    s_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                      criteria_ba1[1, 2]))$suboptimal)
    cond_data <-
      mutate(cond_data,!!as.character(paste0(criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_o")) := o_col, .keep = c("all"))
    cond_data <-
      mutate(cond_data,!!as.character(paste0(criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_s")) := s_col, .keep = c("all"))
    
    n = 2
    fpm_conc_var <-
      c(as.character(paste0(criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_o")), as.character(paste0(criteria_ba1[1, 2], "_s")), "x" , "y")
    fpm_conc_name <-
      c(as.character(paste0(criteria_suit[1, 4], " optimal")), as.character(paste0(criteria_suit[1, 4], " suboptimal")))
    fpm_plot_title <-
      "Biophysical Aptitude membership"
    
    plot_fpm <- rasterize_plot_fpm(n, fpm_conc_var, fpm_conc_name, cond_data)
```

```{r rulebases_ba_nuance01, echo=FALSE, results='asis', eval=ba_crit}
cat("### Combined Biophysical Aptitude - eight class rule bases

 - Attempt to add some nuance to the consequent attributes of the biophysical aptitude to mirror the FAO suitability classes - S1, S2, S3, N1, N2

Class S1 land has no significant limitations to sustained application of a given use. It may include minor limitations that will not reduce productivity, benefits or costs below the lower boundary set for the class.

Class S2 land has limitations which in aggregate are moderately severe for sustained application of a given use. The limitations may reduce physical productivity, benefits or costs compared with S1 land to a lower limit set for the class.

Class S3 land has limitations which in aggregate are severe for sustained application of a given use and will so reduce physical productivity, benefits or costs that the expenditure will only be marginally justified.

Note: A Conditionally Suitable (Sc) class may be used in certain instances of uncertainty, or where factors relevant to suitability are not yet fully understood. However, this is discouraged, and in classifying 'provisionally-irrigable' land the uncertainty about water supply and costs are assumed to be unresolved. The use of class Sc may seem convenient to an evaluator, but in excess it would greatly complicate the understanding of the classification by users.

Class N1 indicates that the land is marginally not suitable and has limitations that may be surmountable in time but which cannot be corrected with the existing knowledge or under present social conditions to give acceptable physical productivity. It indicates the economic limit defining the boundary between 'Suitable' and 'Not Suitable'.

Class N2 indicates that the land is permanently not suitable for the given use usually because of physical limitations. N2 land should be delineated early in the study to avoid unnecessary studies on land which will never be developed for the given use. In contrast, the boundary between the two Orders, S and N, may be variable over time due to changes in economic and social conditions.

")
```

```{r rulebases_sef09, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, results='asis', warning=FALSE, eval=sef_crit}

# new proposition object is made here
prop <- new("Proposition", table = p_tib)
prop_table <- prop@table
n_prop <- ncol(prop_table)


# new conclusion object is made here

conc <- new("Conclusion", table = c_tib)

# create a rule base
rb_se_1 <- RuleBase(prop, conc) %>% print()


# in this section there are normally two criteria - fp feasibility and market access

# fp feasibility is based on two criteria and has a rb (se_2a) and includes management and inputs and their two rb (se_3a & se3b).
# management is based on two criteria: extension and labour their two rb (se_4a & se4b).
# Extension includes two further criteria with rule bases (se_5a & se_5b) each with fuzzy partitions.
# Access to labour is based on two criteria and their two rb (se_5c & se5d) each with fuzzy partitions.

# farm inputs is based on three criteria: access to seeds and land and their two rb (se_4d & se4e) each with fuzzy partitions.
# Access to fertilisers and pesticides has a rb (se_4c) and includes two criteria and their two rb (se_5e & se5f) each with fuzzy partitions.
``` 

```{r rulebases_adoption09, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, results='asis', warning=FALSE, eval=adop_crit}
# in this section there are normally two criteria - b aptitude and se feasibility

# se feasibility is based on two criteria and has a rb (se_1) and includes fp feasibility and market access and their two rb (se_2a & se2b).

# fp feasibility is based on two criteria and has a rb (se_2a) and includes management and inputs and their two rb (se_3a & se3b).
# management is based on two criteria: extension and labour their two rb (se_4a & se4b).
# Extension includes two further criteria with rule bases (se_5a & se_5b) each with fuzzy partitions.
# Access to labour is based on two criteria and their two rb (se_5c & se5d) each with fuzzy partitions.

# farm inputs is based on three criteria: access to seeds and land and their two rb (se_4d & se4e) each with fuzzy partitions.
# Access to fertilisers and pesticides has a rb (se_4c) and includes two criteria and their two rb (se_5e & se5f) each with fuzzy partitions.

# market access has a rb (se_2b) and includes three criteria and their three rb (se_3c, se_3d & se3e) each with fuzzy partitions.

# there are eleven fp in total (se_3c, se_3d, se3e, se_4d, se_4e, se_5a, se_5b, se_5c, se5d, se_5e and se_5f)

  )

  )


tmp_rbs <-  assign(paste0("rbs_adop_0"), eval(parse(text = x)))

# evaluate the rule base stack

w <-
  paste("predict(",
        "tmp_rbs, newdata = cond_data,",
        gsub(",$", "", paste0(
          get(paste0("fp_adop_0_list")), sep = ",", collapse = ""
        )),
        ")")

fpm_adop_0 <- eval(parse(text = w))


# write the membership values to cond_data and plot the maps of the conclusions

}

if (sef_rb == "hml") {

    }
    
    adop_rb <- "hml"
  }
  
} else {

  adop_rule_num <- 4
  
  if (adop_conclusion2 == "moderate" |
      adop_conclusion3 == "moderate") {
    m_col <- getMembership(fpm_adop_0$moderate)
    
    # add column only if column doesn't already exist in cond_data
    
    if ("adop_0_m" %in% colnames(cond_data)) {
``` 

```{r rulebases_adoption_nuance08, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, results='asis', warning=FALSE, eval=adop_crit}

# new proposition object is made here
prop <- new("Proposition", table = p_tib)
prop_table <- prop@table
n_prop <- ncol(prop_table)


# new conclusion object is made here

conc <- new("Conclusion", table = c_tib)

# create a rule base
rb_adop_0_nuance <- RuleBase(prop, conc) %>% print()


# in this section there are normally two criteria - b aptitude and se feasibility

# biophysical aptitude is based on five criteria and has a rb (ba_1) and includes Land Use Aptitude, Climatic Aptitude, Soil Physical Properties Aptitude, Soil Fertility Aptitude, Landscape Aptitude (ba_2a, ba_2b, ba_2c, ba_2d, ba_2e)





# se feasibility is based on two criteria and has a rb (se_1) and includes fp feasibility and market access and their two rb (se_2a & se2b).

# fp feasibility is based on two criteria and has a rb (se_2a) and includes management and inputs and their two rb (se_3a & se3b).
# management is based on two criteria: extension and labour their two rb (se_4a & se4b).
# Extension includes two further criteria with rule bases (se_5a & se_5b) each with fuzzy partitions.
# Access to labour is based on two criteria and their two rb (se_5c & se5d) each with fuzzy partitions.

# farm inputs is based on three criteria: access to seeds and land and their two rb (se_4d & se4e) each with fuzzy partitions.
# Access to fertilisers and pesticides has a rb (se_4c) and includes two criteria and their two rb (se_5e & se5f) each with fuzzy partitions.

# market access has a rb (se_2b) and includes three criteria and their three rb (se_3c, se_3d & se3e) each with fuzzy partitions.

# there are eleven fp in total (se_3c, se_3d, se3e, se_4d, se_4e, se_5a, se_5b, se_5c, se5d, se_5e and se_5f)

x <-
  paste(
    "stack(",
    gsub(",$", "", paste0(
      get("rbs_ba_1_nuance_list"),
      sep = ",",
      collapse = ""
    )),
    ",rb_se_5a,rb_se_5b,rb_se_4a,rb_se_5c,rb_se_5d,rb_se_4b,rb_se_3a,rb_se_5e,rb_se_5f,rb_se_4c,rb_se_4d,rb_se_4e,rb_se_3b,rb_se_2a,rb_se_3c,rb_se_3d,rb_se_3e,rb_se_2b,rb_se_1,rb_adop_0_nuance)"
  )

fp_adop_0_nuance_list <-
  append(
    fp_ba_1_nuance_list,
    "se_3c = fp_se_3c,se_3d = fp_se_3d,se_3e = fp_se_3e,se_4d = fp_se_4d,se_4e = fp_se_4e,se_5a = fp_se_5a,se_5b = fp_se_5b,se_5c = fp_se_5c,se_5d = fp_se_5d,se_5e = fp_se_5e,se_5f = fp_se_5f"
  )


tmp_rbs <-
  assign(paste0("rbs_adop_0_nuance"), eval(parse(text = x)))

# evaluate the rule base stack

w <-
  paste("predict(",
        "tmp_rbs, newdata = cond_data,",
        gsub(",$", "", paste0(
          get(paste0("fp_adop_0_nuance_list")), sep = ",", collapse = ""
        )),
        ")")

fpm_adop_0_nuance <- eval(parse(text = w))

S2se_col <- getMembership(fpm_adop_0_nuance$S2se)
``` 

```{r classified_adop_membership_maps04 , cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, fig.width=8, fig.height=7, out.width="100%", message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, timeit = TRUE, eval=adop_crit}
# create classified adoption map 

if (params$RES1 != 2) {
  # new method because of cond_data dropped no data
  
  if (adop_rb == "hml") {
    d0 <-
      cond_data %>% dplyr::select(adop_0_h, adop_0_m, adop_0_l, x , y) %>% na.omit %>% vect(geom = c("x", "y"))
    d1 <- rasterize(d0, rast_mask_proj, field = "adop_0_h")
    d2 <- rasterize(d0, rast_mask_proj, field = "adop_0_m")
    d3 <- rasterize(d0, rast_mask_proj, field = "adop_0_l")
    dB_adop <- rast(list(d1, d2, d3))
    names(dB_adop) <- c('high', 'moderate', 'low')
    
    # get max value and export
    dM <- which.max(dB_adop)
    dM_brick <- rast(list(d1, d2, d3, dM))
    names(dM_brick) <- c('high', 'moderate', 'low', 'class')
    output_geotiff(dM_brick, paste0("3class_adop0_", params$INN1))
    
  } else {
    d0 <-
      cond_data %>% dplyr::select(adop_h, adop_l, x , y) %>% na.omit %>% vect(geom = c("x", "y"))
    d1 <- rasterize(d0, rast_mask_proj, field = "adop_0_h")
    d2 <- rasterize(d0, rast_mask_proj, field = "adop_0_l")
    dB_adop <- rast(list(d1, d2))
    names(dB_adop) <- c('high', 'low')
    
    # get max value and export
    dM <- which.max(dB_adop)
    dM_brick <- rast(list(d1, d2, dM))
    names(dM_brick) <- c('high', 'low', 'class')
    output_geotiff(dM_brick, paste0("2class_adop0_", params$INN1))
    
  }

  d_adop <- dB_adop %>%
    as.data.frame(xy = TRUE) %>%
    na.omit
  m <- d_adop %>% dplyr::select(-x,-y)
  
  d_adop$class <- names(m)[apply(X = m, MARGIN = 1, FUN = which.max)]
  d_adop$class <-
    factor(d_adop$class,
           levels = c("low", "moderate", "high"),
           ordered = TRUE)
  
  g <- ggplot(data = d_adop) +
    geom_raster(mapping = aes(x = x, y = y, fill = class)) +
    scale_x_continuous(
      name = "",
      labels = function(x) {
        1.0e-3 * x
      }
    ) +
    scale_y_continuous(
      name = "",
      labels = function(x) {
        1.0e-3 * x
      }
    ) +
    scale_fill_manual(
      name = paste0("Likelihood\nfor Adoption\n", params$INN1),
      values = c(
        high = rgb(0, 158, 115, maxColorValue = 255),
        low  = rgb(213,  94,   0, maxColorValue = 255),
        moderate = rgb(230, 159, 0, maxColorValue = 255)
      ),
      drop = FALSE
    ) +
    coord_equal()
  
g2 <- add_subdiv_proj_simple_plot(g)
g2  
} # end RES if statement 08/12/2019
``` 

# Calculate yields and production

## Yield proportion

The IRM script already calculates the optimality of the individual criteria as well as the climatic, landscape, soil fertility and soil physical properties groups of criteria.

The first method of calculating yield will calculate the product of the optimality of selected criteria.


```{r calc_yield_1, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg,fig.width=30,  out.width="100%", include = TRUE, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, eval=ba_crit}

# get the criteria that contribute to yield

rbyielddf1 <- dplyr::select(priorities, "rulebase_number","criterion","yield") %>% dplyr::filter(!is.na(yield))

rbyielddf1 %>% kable(digits = 3) %>% kable_styling("striped", full_width = T)  %>%  scroll_box(height = "500px")
# make an expression using the rule base numbers

yield_expr <- paste("cond_data$yieldpc <- (")

for (i in seq(from = 1,
              to = nrow(rbyielddf1),
              by = 1)) {
  yield_expr <- paste0(yield_expr, "cond_data$" , as.character(rbyielddf1[i, 1]), "_o * ")
  
}
yield_expr <- paste(yield_expr, " 100)")
yield_expr

# evaluate the expression
eval(str2expression(yield_expr))
str(cond_data$yieldpc)
if (summarise(cond_data, Average = mean(yieldpc, na.rm = T)) > 0) {

# cond_data <- dplyr::select(cond_data,-yield)

cond_data_sf <- cond_data %>% na.omit %>% vect(geom = c("x", "y"))

dBy <- rasterize(cond_data_sf, ra_mask, field="yieldpc")
names(dBy) <- c('yieldpc')

# export
output_geotiff(dBy, paste0("yieldpc_", params$INN1))

  dy <- dBy %>%
    as.data.frame(xy = TRUE) %>%
    na.omit

  
  gy <- ggplot(data = dy) +
    geom_raster(mapping = aes(x = x, y = y, fill = yieldpc)) +
    scale_fill_stepsn(
      n.breaks = 10,
      limits = c(0, 100),
      colours = hcl.colors(palette = "Greens", 10, rev = TRUE),
      guide = "legend"
    ) +
    scale_x_continuous(
      name = "",
      labels = function(x) {
        1.0e-3 * x
      }
    ) +
    scale_y_continuous(
      name = "",
      labels = function(x) {
        1.0e-3 * x
      }
    ) +
    coord_equal()
  
gy2 <- add_subdiv_plot(gy, paste(params$SUBDIV1))
gy2
}
```

## Calculate yield

The IRM script converts yield proportion to yield using the yield values for sole crop or intercrop.


```{r calc_yield_2, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg,fig.width=12,  out.width="100%", include = TRUE, echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, eval=ba_crit}

# get the criteria that contribute to yield

yield_filename <-
  as.character(paste("tab_data/input/yield_", params$INN1, ".csv", sep = ""))
yield_tab <- read.csv(here(yield_filename), na.strings = c("NA"))

yield_tab %>% kable(digits = 3) %>% kable_styling("striped", full_width = T)  %>%  scroll_box(height = "100px")


if (params$INN2 == "NA") {
  cond_data$yield <- cond_data$yieldpc / 100 * yield_tab$YA
  cat("Sole crop yield")
} else {
  cond_data$yield <- cond_data$yieldpc / 100 * yield_tab$YI
  cat("Intercrop yield")
}

if (summarise(cond_data, Average = mean(yield, na.rm = T)) > 0) {
  
cond_data_sfp <-
  cond_data %>% na.omit %>% vect(geom = c("x", "y"))

dByd <- rasterize(cond_data_sfp, ra_mask, field = "yield")
names(dByd) <- c('yield')

# export
output_geotiff(dByd, paste0("yield_", params$INN1))

dyd <- dByd %>%
  as.data.frame(xy = TRUE) %>%
  na.omit


gyd <- ggplot(data = dyd) +
  geom_raster(mapping = aes(x = x, y = y, fill = yield)) +
  scale_fill_stepsn(
    n.breaks = 10,
    colours = hcl.colors(palette = "OrRd", 10, rev = TRUE),
    guide = "legend",
    labels = comma
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    name = "",
    labels = function(x) {
      1.0e-3 * x
    }
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    name = "",
    labels = function(x) {
      1.0e-3 * x
    }
  ) +
  coord_equal()

gyd2 <- add_subdiv_plot(gyd, paste(params$SUBDIV1))
gyd2
}
```

# Basic Settings

## Parameters, Criteria and Rule Bases

Here we load some parameters used in the IRM model, load the table of criteria and their threshold values, weights (if relevant) and data, and display the rule bases in a graphical diagramme. 

### Parameters and Criteria

<div class="fold o"> 
```{r parameters_location_i2, results='asis'}

# Each innovation has potentially different growing periods, rule bases, rule base priorities, and thresholds

# The next set of parameters are for the priorities of the socio-economic rule base.
# Following this there are parameters for the growing period length.
# There then follow parameters for thresholds and threshold widths

# get the priorities filename using the innovation parameter
priorities_filename <-
  as.character(paste("tab_data/input/priorities_", params$INN2, ".csv", sep = ""))

priorities <- read.csv(here(priorities_filename), na.strings = c("NA"))

priorities %>%

kable(digits = 3) %>% kable_styling("striped", full_width = T) %>%
  row_spec(0, angle = -45) %>%  scroll_box(height = "500px")
```
</div>

### Rule Base Diagramme

Boxes in green show basic rule bases which have data and a fuzzy partition defined. Circles in red are complex rule base stacks, which depend on the results of other rule bases. 

<div class="fold o"> 
```{r rule_base_graphs_i2, results='asis'}

# In this chunk we will use the DiagrammeR package to produce a graph diagram of the rule bases, using the information provided by the priorities csv file loaded in the previous chunk.

# the DiagrammeR package expects a valid graph specification in the DOT language. The graph is a kind of network with nodes and edges. For our purposes the nodes are the criteria and the rule bases. The edges are directed lines that show how each contributes and can also the weight of each criteria (or the results of previously run rule bases)

# the graph has a statement followed by the list of nodes and edges

# in this chunk we will construct the string that is equivalent to a .gv file


# this creates a new df with a string of rulebase number and labels

rbnumberdf1 <- unite(priorities, "id_label0", "rulebase_number","criterion", sep = " [ label = '", remove = FALSE, na.rm = FALSE)
rbnumberdf1 <- unite(rbnumberdf1, "id_label1", "id_label0", "rulebase_number", sep = " \n", remove = FALSE, na.rm = FALSE)
rbnumberdf1$cl_br <- c(" ']")
rbnumberdf1 <- unite(rbnumberdf1, "id_label", "id_label1","cl_br", sep = "", remove = TRUE, na.rm = FALSE)

rbstacklist1 <- rbnumberdf1[,"rulebase_stack"]  
rbstacklist2 <- rbstacklist1[!is.na(rbstacklist1)] 
rbstacklist3 <- unique(rbstacklist2)
rbstacklist4 <- paste(rbstacklist3, collapse=";")

rbnumberlist1 <- rbnumberdf1[,"rulebase_number"]  
rbnumberlist2 <- rbnumberlist1[!is.na(rbnumberlist1)] 
rbnumberlist3 <- unique(rbnumberlist2)
rbnumberlist4 <- rbnumberlist3[rbnumberlist3 %ni% rbstacklist3]
rbnumberlist5 <- paste(rbnumberlist4, collapse=";")

edges1 <- paste(rbnumberlist2,rbstacklist2, sep="->")
edges2 <- paste(edges1, collapse=" ")

rbnumberlabellist1 <- rbnumberdf1[,"id_label"]  
rbnumberlabellist2 <- rbnumberlabellist1[!is.na(rbnumberlist1)] 
rbnumberlabellist3 <- unique(rbnumberlabellist2)
rbnumberlabellist4 <- rbnumberlabellist3[rbnumberlist3 %ni% rbstacklist3]
rbnumberlabellist5 <- paste(rbnumberlabellist4, collapse=";")

rbstacklabellist1 <- rbnumberdf1[,"id_label"]
rbstacklabellist2 <- rbstacklabellist1[!is.na(rbstacklist1)] 
rbstacklabellist3 <- rbstacklabellist2[rbnumberlist3 %in% rbstacklist3]
rbstacklabellist4 <- paste(rbstacklabellist3, collapse=";")

rulebasegraph_name <- paste("digraph simple_rule_base")
rulebasegraph_graph_stmt <- paste("graph [overlap = true, fontsize = 100, fontname = Calibri, rankdir = LR, label = 'Rule bases for ", params$INN2, "', labelloc = t]")
rulebasegraph_node_stmt <- paste("node [shape = box, fontsize = 50, fontname = Helvetica, color = 'DarkOliveGreen4', fillcolor = 'OliveDrab2', style = filled]",
  rbnumberlabellist5,
  "node [shape = oval, fixedsize = false, width = 0.9, color = 'red', fillcolor = 'IndianRed3', fontsize = 50, fontname = Helvetica, style = filled] ",
  rbstacklabellist4
  )

rulebasegraph_edge_stmt <- paste(edges2)

rulebasegraph <- paste(rulebasegraph_name, "{", rulebasegraph_graph_stmt, rulebasegraph_node_stmt, rulebasegraph_edge_stmt, "}")

grViz(rulebasegraph)

#frameWidget(grViz(rulebasegraph) , options = frameOptions(allowfullscreen = FALSE))


#knitr::knit_exit() # this stops knitting useful for debugging
```
</div>

```{r growth_stages02_i2, results='asis', eval=grs_crit}
  # get the growth stages filename using the innovation parameter
  growth_stages_filename <-
    as.character(paste("tab_data/input/growth_stages_", params$INN2, ".csv", sep = ""))
  
  growth_stages <-  read.csv(here(growth_stages_filename))
  
  growth_stages %>%
    kable(digits = 3, caption = "Growth Stage Lengths") %>% kable_styling("striped", full_width = T) %>% print
  
# create a new table just for where growth stage has requirements
growth_stages_req <- dplyr::filter(growth_stages, criteria == 1)  
  
  
  
  # get the number of variables in growth_stages (excluding sowing/planting date and total length)
  
  # create a list of the growth stages and determine the start and end days of each growth period
  phen_tmp <- list()
  for (i in 1:(nrow(growth_stages) - 2)) {
    phen_tmp[[as.character(growth_stages[i + 2, 1])]] <-
      growth_stages[i + 2, 3]
  }
  
  phen_stages_beg <-
    growth_stages$day[1] + c(0, cumsum(phen_tmp)[-length(phen_tmp)])
  phen_stages_end <- growth_stages$day[1] + cumsum(phen_tmp)
  names(phen_stages_beg) <- names(phen_stages_end)
  
  # add the total to the growth stages
  
  phen_stages_beg[["total"]] <- growth_stages[1, 2]
  phen_stages_end[["total"]] <-
    sum(growth_stages[1, 2], growth_stages[2, 3])
  
  rbind(start = phen_stages_beg, end = phen_stages_end) %>%
    as.data.frame %>%
    kable(caption = "Growth Stage Days") %>% kable_styling("striped", full_width = T)  %>% print
  
  
  num_years <- ceiling(phen_stages_end[["total"]] / 365)
  cat(paste("Growth Stages span", num_years, "calendar years"))
```

# Common spatial resolution and extent

## Mask

Let's start with creating a 'mask', _i.e._, a raster map of the area of interest (1 = area to be modelled, NA = ignored). 

The properties of this map are given below:

```{r mask01_i2, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, out.width="100%", warning=FALSE}
ra_mask
```

A factor is calculated to determine the area of each raster cell in hectares.

```{r mask02_i2, cache = FALSE, warning=FALSE }

```

## Reproject, Aggregate and Resample

<div class="fold o">   
```{r agg_resample_01_i2, cache = TRUE, out.width="100%", results='asis', warning=FALSE}

for (i in seq(from = 1,
              to = nrow(raster_data_df),
              by = 1)) {

# reproject the raster data if necessary

# compare the crs of the raster with the working crs
# when different project the raster  
  
  if ( paste(crs(get(paste0("r_", raster_data_df[i, 11])))) %ni% paste(crs_irm)) {  
  
  assign(
    paste0("r_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_prj"),
    raster_project(
      get(paste0("r_", raster_data_df[i, 11])),
      crs_irm,
      as.character(raster_data_df[i, 14])
    )
  )  
  } else {

# when not different just create a new raster with the same prj suffix  
    assign(
    paste0("r_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_prj"),
    get(paste0("r_", raster_data_df[i, 11]))
      )
  }

# calculate aggregate factor for each criterion for both dimensions of the raster (these are the same for a square cell shape)
  
  cat(paste(raster_data_df[i, 10]))
  calc_agg_factor <-
    (res(ra_mask) / res(get(paste0(
      "r_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_prj"
    ))))
  cat(paste("calculated aggregate factor = ", calc_agg_factor))
  cat("\n")
  
  if (calc_agg_factor[1] < 1) {
    calc_agg_factor[1] <- 1
    
    # this means that the mask has a higher resolution than the precipitation raster so aggregation is not necessary and the precipitation raster will stay the same resolution
    
    cat(paste("revised calculated aggregate factor 1 = ", calc_agg_factor[1]))
  }
  
  cat("\n")
  
  if (calc_agg_factor[2] < 1) {
    calc_agg_factor[2] <- 1
    cat(paste("revised calculated aggregate factor 2 = ", calc_agg_factor[2]))
  }
  
  # for each record in the raster_data_df data frame use the data file prefix to recreate the raster name, and the aggregation and resample functions
  
  assign(
    paste0("r_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_rsmp"),
    agg_resample(
      get(paste0("r_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_prj")),
      calc_agg_factor,
      get(paste(raster_data_df[i, 13])),
      as.character(raster_data_df[i, 14])
    )
  )
  
  plot_raster <-
    plot(
      get(paste0("r_", raster_data_df[i, 11], "_rsmp")),
      title = paste0(
        as.character(raster_data_df[i, 10]),
        "\nagg ",
        as.character(raster_data_df[i, 13]),
        "\nrsmp ",
        as.character(raster_data_df[i, 14])
      ),
      n = 10
    )
  print(plot_raster)
  plot(ra_mask, title = "") # this is needed (even if it is not actually plotted) to enable the plot of the raster
  
}

```

```{r requirements_prec04_i2, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, fig.width=7, fig.height=4, out.width="100%", fig.show="hold", warning=FALSE, eval=prec_crit, eval=grs_crit}

for (i in 1:(nrow(criteria_ba3a))) {
  if (!is.na(criteria_ba3a[i, 18])) {
    # for those criteria with three proposition values
    # get  the 3 proposition levels
    prop_levels <-
      c(
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 16]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 17]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 18])
      )
    
    # get  the 3 conclusion levels
    conc_levels <-
      c(
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 20]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 21])
      )
    # get  the 2 crossover points
    cross_points <-
      c(criteria_ba3a[i, 6],
        criteria_ba3a[i, 7])
    
    # get  the 2 transition widths
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_ba3a[i, 8],
        criteria_ba3a[i, 9])
    
    # get  the 2 xlims for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_ba3a[i, 6] - criteria_ba3a[i, 8]),
        (criteria_ba3a[i, 7] + criteria_ba3a[i, 9]))
    
    
  } else {
    # for those criteria with two proposition values
    # get  the 2 proposition levels
    prop_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 16]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 17]))
    
    # get  the 2 conclusion levels
    conc_levels <-
      c(as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 19]),
        as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 20]))
    
    # get  the 1 crossover point
    cross_points <-
      c(criteria_ba3a[i, 6])
    
    # get  the 1 transition width
    trans_width <-
      c(criteria_ba3a[i, 8])
    
    # get  the 1 xlim for the plot
    plot_xlim <-
      c((criteria_ba3a[i, 6] - criteria_ba3a[i, 8]),
        (criteria_ba3a[i, 6] + criteria_ba3a[i, 8]))
    
  }
  assign(
    paste0("fp_", criteria_ba3a[i, 3]),
    LinearFuzzyPartition(
      level =  prop_levels,
      crossoverPoint  = cross_points,
      transitionWidth = trans_width
    )
  )
  
  plot_fp <-
    plot(
      get(paste0("fp_", criteria_ba3a[i, 3])),
      xlim = plot_xlim,
      xlab = as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 4]),
      title = "fuzzy partition"
    )
  print(plot_fp)
  
  # construct the rule bases
  
  
  # set the proposition name
  Prop_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 3]))
  # set the conclusion name
  Conc_name <-
    paste0(as.character(criteria_ba3a[i, 3]),
           "_o")
  
  # thanks to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45741498/add-column-in-tibble-with-variable-column-name for the following dynamic assignment of variable names in a tibble
  
  # set the proposition values
  p_tib <- tibble(!!Prop_name := c(prop_levels))
  # set the conclusion values
  c_tib <- tibble(!!Conc_name := c(conc_levels))
  
  # new proposition and conclusion class objects are made here
  new_prop <- new("Proposition", table = p_tib)
  new_conc <- new("Conclusion", table = c_tib)
  
  assign(paste0("rb_",
                criteria_ba3a[i, 3]),
         
         RuleBase(new_prop, new_conc))
  
  print(get(paste0("rb_",
                   criteria_ba3a[i, 3])))
  
  # apply the fuzzy partitions to the data
  
  # first construct the predict function with all arguments as text
  
  x <- paste0(
    "predict(rb_",
    criteria_ba3a[i, 3],
    ", newdata = cond_data_i2,",
    criteria_ba3a[i, 3],
    "=",
    "fp_",
    criteria_ba3a[i, 3],
    ")"
  )
  
  
  assign(paste0("fpm_",
                criteria_ba3a[i, 3]), eval(parse(text = x)))
  
  
  o_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_ba3a[i, 3]))$optimal)
  s_col <- getMembership(get(paste0("fpm_",
                                    criteria_ba3a[i, 3]))$suboptimal)
  cond_data_i2 <-
    add_column(cond_data_i2,!!as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 3], "_o")) := o_col)
  cond_data_i2 <-
    add_column(cond_data_i2,!!as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 3], "_s")) := s_col)
  
  n = 2
  fpm_conc_var <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 3], "_o")), as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 3], "_s")), "x" , "y")
  fpm_conc_name <-
    c(as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 4], " optimal")), as.character(paste0(criteria_ba3a[i, 4], " suboptimal")))
  fpm_plot_title <-
    "Precipitation growth\nstages optimality\nmembership"
  
  plot_fpm <- rasterize_plot_fpm(n, fpm_conc_var, fpm_conc_name, cond_data_i2)
  print(plot_fpm)
  
  
}
``` 

```{r requirements_soilp01_i2, echo=FALSE, results='asis', eval=soil_p_crit}
cat("### Soil physical properties requirements

If soil texture is a criterion then the USDA codes are reclassified quantitatively so that the fuzzy partitions can be applied.

Soil texture classes are reclassified in with 1, corresponding to S1 in Sys _et al._ (1993, p.159), 0.5 corresponding to S2, and 0 corresponding to S3, N1, N2 in Sys _et al._. 

An example is shown in the table below: 
 
USDA Class | USDA Texture Code | Suitability | Value 
-----------|-------------------|-------------|-------
     '1'   |     'Cl'          |  S2         |  0.5
     '2'   |     'SiCl'        |  S1         |  1
     '3'   |     'SaCl'        |  S1         |  1
     '4'   |     'ClLo'        |  S1         |  1
     '5'   |     'SiClLo'      |  S1         |  1
     '6'   |     'SaClLo'      |  S1         |  1
     '7'   |     'Lo'          |  S1         |  1
     '8'   |     'SiLo'        |  S1         |  1
     '9'   |     'SaLo'        |  S1         |  1
    '10'   |     'Si'          |  S1         |  1
    '11'   |     'LoSa'        |  S1         |  1
    '12'   |     'Sa'          |  S3         |  0
   '255'   |     'NODATA'      |  NA         |  NA")
```

```{r requirements_soilp02_i2, results='asis', warning=FALSE, eval=soil_p_crit}

# Each innovation has potentially different criteria and rule bases

# In this chunk we need to know which data to load for the criteria

criteria_ba2c <-
  subset(priorities, grepl("^ba_2c", priorities$rulebase_stack)) # use regular expressions to find criteria
n_cba2c <- nrow(criteria_ba2c)
cat(paste(n_cba2c, "Soil physical properties criteria:\n\n"))

# then determine and print the names of the rule bases in the soil physical properties theme
cat(paste(n_cba2c, "Soil physical properties rule bases:\n\n"))
for (i in 1:n_cba2c) {
  cat(paste(criteria_ba2c[i, 3],"\n", criteria_ba2c[i, 4],"\n"))
  
  if (paste(criteria_ba2c[i, 4]) == "Soil texture") {
    soil_texture_filename <-
      as.character(paste("tab_data/input/usda_texture_", params$INN2, ".csv", sep = ""))
    
    soil_texture <-  read.csv(here(soil_texture_filename))
    
    soil_texture %>%
      kable(digits = 3, caption = "Soil Texture ") %>% kable_styling("striped", full_width = T) %>% print
    
    # reclass using soil_texture table
    
    r_texture <-
      get(paste0("r_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp")) %>% reclassify(as.matrix(
        dplyr::select(soil_texture, USDA_Texture_Class, IRM_Value)
      ))
    
    
    #     r_texture <-
    #       get(paste0("r_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp")) %>% calc(function(x) {
    #          is_na <- x > 254.5
    #          is_s1 <- ((x > 0.5) & (x < 1.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 1 "Cl" clay
    #                   ((x > 1.5) & (x < 2.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 2 "SiCl" silty clay
    #                   ((x > 2.5) & (x < 3.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 3 "SaCl" sandy  clay
    #                   ((x > 3.5) & (x < 4.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 4 "ClLo" clay loam
    #                   ((x > 4.5) & (x < 5.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 5 "SiClLo" silty clay #loam
    #                   ((x > 5.5) & (x < 6.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 6 "SaClLo" sandy clay #loam
    #                   ((x > 6.5) & (x < 7.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 7 "Lo" loam
    #                   ((x > 7.5) & (x < 8.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 8 "SiLo" silty loam
    #                   ((x > 8.5) & (x < 9.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 9 "SaLo" sandy loam
    #                   ((x > 9.5) & (x < 10.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 10 "Si" silt
    #                   ((x > 10.5) & (x < 11.5)) | # USDA Texture Class 11 "LoSa" loamy #sand
    #                   ((x > 11.5) & (x < 12.5))   # USDA Texture Class 12 "Sa" sand
    #          x[is_s1] <- 1
    #          x[!is_s1] <- 0
    #          x[is_na] <- NA
    #          x
    #        })
    
    assign(paste0("r_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"),  r_texture[[1:5]])
    
    # standard depths for interpolation
    standard_depths <- c(0.025, 0.10, 0.225, 0.45, 0.80, 1.50)
    
    # thicknesses of individual layers
    bottom_layer <- c(0.05, 0.15, 0.30, 0.60, 1.0)
    thickness <- diff(c(0, bottom_layer))
    stopifnot(max(abs(
      bottom_layer - 0.5 *  thickness - standard_depths[1:5]
    )) < 1.0e-6)
    
    # depth weighted texture class (0-1)
    assign(paste0("r_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"),
           get(paste0("r_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp")) %>% calc(function(x) {
             sum((x * thickness) / sum(thickness))
           }))
  } else if (paste(criteria_ba2c[i, 4]) == "Coarse fragments") {
    assign(paste0("r_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"),  get(paste0("r_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"))[[1:5]])
    
    # standard depths for interpolation
    standard_depths <- c(0.025, 0.10, 0.225, 0.45, 0.80, 1.50)
    
    # thicknesses of individual layers
    bottom_layer <- c(0.05, 0.15, 0.30, 0.60, 1.0)
    thickness <- diff(c(0, bottom_layer))
    stopifnot(max(abs(
      bottom_layer - 0.5 *  thickness - standard_depths[1:5]
    )) < 1.0e-6)
    
    # depth weighted map
    assign(paste0("r_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp"),
           get(paste0("r_", criteria_ba2c[i, 11], "_rsmp")) %>% calc(function(x) {
             sum((x * thickness) / sum(thickness))
           }))
  }
}
```

# Rule Base Creation and Evaluation

We will not construct one big rule base but follow a hierarchical approach consisting of many small interrelated rule bases for the following reasons:

- one big rule base is hard, if not impossible, to understand
- a set of smaller hierarchically organised rule bases gives more information about the limiting factors
- a hierarchically structured rule base is much faster and less memory demanding.
- a hierarchically structured rule base gives exactly the same results as one big rule base.

If we have both bio-physical and socio-economic criteria then these have separate rule bases, and are combined to give the Likelihood for Adoption.

```{r rulebases_ba01_i2, echo=FALSE, results='asis', eval=ba_crit}
By constructing and evaluating smaller thematic rule bases it is possible to identify criteria that limit the biophysical aptitude.
")
```

```{r rulebases_ba_nuance01_i2, echo=FALSE, results='asis', eval=ba_crit}
cat("### Combined Biophysical Aptitude - eight class rule bases

 - Attempt to add some nuance to the consequent attributes of the biophysical aptitude to mirror the FAO suitability classes - S1, S2, S3, N1, N2

Class S1 land has no significant limitations to sustained application of a given use. It may include minor limitations that will not reduce productivity, benefits or costs below the lower boundary set for the class.

Class S2 land has limitations which in aggregate are moderately severe for sustained application of a given use. The limitations may reduce physical productivity, benefits or costs compared with S1 land to a lower limit set for the class.

Class S3 land has limitations which in aggregate are severe for sustained application of a given use and will so reduce physical productivity, benefits or costs that the expenditure will only be marginally justified.

Note: A Conditionally Suitable (Sc) class may be used in certain instances of uncertainty, or where factors relevant to suitability are not yet fully understood. However, this is discouraged, and in classifying 'provisionally-irrigable' land the uncertainty about water supply and costs are assumed to be unresolved. The use of class Sc may seem convenient to an evaluator, but in excess it would greatly complicate the understanding of the classification by users.

Class N1 indicates that the land is marginally not suitable and has limitations that may be surmountable in time but which cannot be corrected with the existing knowledge or under present social conditions to give acceptable physical productivity. It indicates the economic limit defining the boundary between 'Suitable' and 'Not Suitable'.

Class N2 indicates that the land is permanently not suitable for the given use usually because of physical limitations. N2 land should be delineated early in the study to avoid unnecessary studies on land which will never be developed for the given use. In contrast, the boundary between the two Orders, S and N, may be variable over time due to changes in economic and social conditions.

")
```

```{r rulebases_adoption_nuance06_i2 , cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, results='asis', timeit = TRUE, warning=FALSE, eval=adop_crit}
if (sef_rb == "hml") {
  # rule 23 only activated when sef is moderate
  
  if (rule1 >= 0.33)  {
    adop_nuance_conclusion23 = "N2"
  } else if (rule1 > -0.33) {
    adop_nuance_conclusion23 = "N2"
  } else {
    adop_nuance_conclusion23 = "S2se"
  }
  cat(paste("rule 23 = ", adop_nuance_conclusion23))
  cat("\n")
  # add to table of conclusions
  c_tib <-
    add_row(c_tib, adop_0_nuance = adop_nuance_conclusion23)
  p_tib <-
    add_row(p_tib,
            ba_1_nuance = "N2",
            se_1 = "moderate")
}   else {
  cat(paste("No rule 23"))
  cat("\n")
}

#Rule 24: If Biophysical Aptitude is N2 and Socio-Economic Feasibility is low then Adoption is N2 or S3@
if (rule1 >= 0.33)  {
  adop_nuance_conclusion24 = "N2"
}     else if (rule1 > -0.33) {
  adop_nuance_conclusion24 = "N2"
} else {
  adop_nuance_conclusion24 = "S3"
}

cat(paste("rule 24 = ", adop_nuance_conclusion24))
cat("\n")
# add to table of conclusions
c_tib <-
  add_row(c_tib, adop_0_nuance = adop_nuance_conclusion24)
p_tib <-
  add_row(p_tib,
          ba_1_nuance = "N2",
          se_1 = "low")
``` 

```{r rulebases_adoption_nuance08_i2, cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, results='asis', warning=FALSE, eval=adop_crit}
# in this section there are normally two criteria - b aptitude and se feasibility

# biophysical aptitude is based on five criteria and has a rb (ba_1) and includes Land Use Aptitude, Climatic Aptitude, Soil Physical Properties Aptitude, Soil Fertility Aptitude, Landscape Aptitude (ba_2a, ba_2b, ba_2c, ba_2d, ba_2e)





# se feasibility is based on two criteria and has a rb (se_1) and includes fp feasibility and market access and their two rb (se_2a & se2b).

# fp feasibility is based on two criteria and has a rb (se_2a) and includes management and inputs and their two rb (se_3a & se3b).
# management is based on two criteria: extension and labour their two rb (se_4a & se4b).
# Extension includes two further criteria with rule bases (se_5a & se_5b) each with fuzzy partitions.
# Access to labour is based on two criteria and their two rb (se_5c & se5d) each with fuzzy partitions.

# farm inputs is based on three criteria: access to seeds and land and their two rb (se_4d & se4e) each with fuzzy partitions.
# Access to fertilisers and pesticides has a rb (se_4c) and includes two criteria and their two rb (se_5e & se5f) each with fuzzy partitions.

# market access has a rb (se_2b) and includes three criteria and their three rb (se_3c, se_3d & se3e) each with fuzzy partitions.

# there are eleven fp in total (se_3c, se_3d, se3e, se_4d, se_4e, se_5a, se_5b, se_5c, se5d, se_5e and se_5f)

  paste(

      get("rbs_ba_1_nuance_list"),

  )


tmp_rbs <-
  assign(paste0("rbs_adop_0_nuance"), eval(parse(text = x)))

# evaluate the rule base stack
``` 

```{r classified_adop_membership_maps04_i2 , cache = TRUE, cache.whatever=params$Agg, fig.width=12, out.width="100%", message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, timeit = TRUE, eval=adop_crit}
      cond_data_i2 %>% dplyr::select(adop_0_h, adop_0_m, adop_0_l, x , y) %>% na.omit %>% vect(geom = c("x", "y"))
    d1_i2 <- rasterize(d0_i2, ra_mask, field = "adop_0_h")

    dB_adop_i2 <- rast(list(d1_i2, d2_i2, d3_i2))
    names(dB_adop_i2) <- c('high', 'moderate', 'low')
    
    # get max value and export
    dM <- which.max(dB_adop_i2)
    dM_brick <- rast(list(d1_i2, d2_i2, d3_i2, dM))
    names(dM_brick) <- c('high', 'moderate', 'low', 'class')
    output_geotiff(dM_brick, paste0("3class_adop0_", params$INN2))
  
  } else {
    d0_i2 <-
      cond_data_i2 %>% dplyr::select(adop_h, adop_l, x , y) %>% na.omit %>% vect(geom = c("x", "y"))
    d1_i2 <- rasterize(d0_i2, ra_mask, field = "adop_0_h")
    d2_i2 <- rasterize(d0_i2, ra_mask, field = "adop_0_l")
    dB_adop_i2 <- rast(list(d1_i2, d2_i2))
    names(dB_adop_i2) <- c('high', 'low')
    
    # get max value and export
    dM <- which.max(dB_adop_i2)
    dM_brick <- rast(list(d1_i2, d2_i2, dM))
    names(dM_brick) <- c('high', 'low', 'class')
    output_geotiff(dM_brick, paste0("2class_adop0_", params$INN2))
  
  }
  
  d_adop_i2 <- dB_adop_i2 %>%
    as.data.frame(xy = TRUE) %>%
    na.omit
  m_i2 <- d_adop_i2 %>% dplyr::select(-x,-y)
  
  d_adop_i2$class <- names(m_i2)[apply(X = m_i2, MARGIN = 1, FUN = which.max)]
  d_adop_i2$class <-
    factor(d_adop_i2$class,
           levels = c("low", "moderate", "high"),
           ordered = TRUE)
  
  g_i2 <- ggplot(data = d_adop_i2) +
    geom_raster(mapping = aes(x = x, y = y, fill = class)) +
    scale_x_continuous(

      labels = function(x) {
        1.0e-3 * x
      }
    ) +
    scale_y_continuous(
      name = "",
      labels = function(x) {
        1.0e-3 * x
      }
    ) +
    scale_fill_manual(
      name = paste0("Likelihood\nfor Adoption\n", params$INN2),
      values = c(
        high = rgb(0, 158, 115, maxColorValue = 255),
        low  = rgb(213,  94,   0, maxColorValue = 255),
        moderate = rgb(230, 159, 0, maxColorValue = 255)
      ),
      drop = FALSE
    ) +
    coord_equal()
  
g2_i2 <- add_subdiv_plot(g_i2, paste(params$SUBDIV2))
g2_i2
``` 
